facts.text: Neneppa Gowdappa had two wives: Kashibai and Sidgangawa I. Kashibai had son Apparaya. Sidgangawa I had son Gowdappa.
Gowdappa had one daughter Gangabai. Apparaya had three children: Neneppa II, Revagowda, and Subhadrabai.
In 1930, Neneppa II was given in adoption to Gowdappa.
Neneppa II had two wives: Kashibai and Sidgangawa II.
Revagowda married Sidgangawa III (daughter of Neneppa II).
In 1938, Revagowda was murdered.

At death of Neneppa I, joint family owned six plots: survey Nos. 43, 59, 65, 66, 69 (137 acres 15 gunthas, Rs. 126/12/- assessment, Borgi Khurd) and No. 77 (14 acres 24 gunthas, Rs. 16/14/-, Borgi Budruk). Total 151 acres 27 gunthas, Rs. 143 assessment.
Between 1911 and 1940, 12 other pieces of land (137 acres 39 gunthas, Rs. 18/10/- assessment) acquired in various names.
Neneppa II murdered in 1944.
After Neneppa II's murder in 1944, Gowdappa and Apparaya denied his adoption and executed partition deed on 28th April 1944 (Ex. 157).
Post-partition alienations: 25-09-1944, Ex.161, Gowdappa gifted S.Nos. 61,62 Borgi Budruk and 45 Borgi Khurd to defendant No.4 Subhadrabai.
01-10-1946, Ex.162, Gowdappa gifted S.Nos.62,63 Borgi Khurd and 11/3 Borgi Budruk to defendant No.3 (daughter of Neneppa II).
20-04-1948, Ex.159, Apparaya sold S.Nos.77 and 43 to defendant No.3 for Rs.5000.
20-04-1948, Ex.160, Gowdappa sold S.No.79 to Apparaya for Rs.1000.
17-05-1948, Ex.158, Gowdappa gifted S.Nos.59 and 60 Borgi Khurd to defendant No.3.
07-12-1948, Ex.117, Gowdappa transferred S.No.66 Borgi Khurd to defendant No.6 (his widowed daughter) by Vardi.
15-12-1948, Gowdappa gave portion of plot No.96 to Sidgangawa (wife of Apparaya) for maintenance.
25-05-1950, Ex.166, Gowdappa and defendant No.1 sold portion of S.No.23 to defendant No.5 for Rs.3000.
19-11-1953, Ex.168, Apparaya's will bequeathed S.No.79 to defendant No.4 and one house to daughter defendant No.4.
Plaintiff claimed to be adopted son of Revagowda, filed suit on 10-06-1954 challenging partition deed as fraudulent, intended to defeat widows' rights, never acted upon, family continued joint.
Defendants contested suit: partition deed genuine, acted upon, brothers separate, alienations genuine.
Trial court: 12 lands (1911-1940) joint family properties; partition sham to defeat widows; most alienations not binding except Ex.159; decree for partition.
Plaintiff filed cross-objection re Ex.159.
Bombay High Court (12-12-1962): Dismissed defendants' appeal, allowed plaintiff's cross-objection, held Ex.159 not binding.
Partition deed recited partition with Panchas help but no names or signatures; unequal division (Gowdappa 101a 39g Rs82/3, Apparaya 50a10g Rs61/7); no mention of house.
Post-partition, brothers continued joint possession, same house, joint mess.
Nucleus income Rs5000-6000 pre-WWI; 8-12 bullocks; self-cultivated; one ancestral land Bagayat.
12 lands total price Rs4800 over 30 years.
Defendant No.1 claimed Gowdappa acquired from cotton business, but no details or evidence.
Defendant No.3 minor at Ex.159 sale; Gowdappa her guardian; no separate property.

legal_issues.text: Whether the partition deed executed by Goudappa and Apparaya on 28th April 1944 was a sham transaction not intended to be effective.
Whether even if partition bogus, there was severance of joint family status by declaration of intention to separate.
Whether the 12 pieces of lands acquired between 1911-1940 were joint family properties or self-acquisitions of Goudappa.
Whether the High Court was right in allowing cross-objection regarding sale deed Ex.159 for survey Nos.43 and 77.

petitioner_arguments.text: Finding that partition sham vitiated as no evidence; partition recited Panchas but none named/signed; unequal but genuine.
Even if bogus, declaration of intention to separate effected severance of joint status.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mitakshara law on severance by unequivocal intention

petitioner_arguments.text: 12 lands self-acquisitions of Goudappa from cotton business.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: No presumption of joint property without nucleus aid

petitioner_arguments.text: Plaintiff did not specifically challenge Ex.159 in plaint para 5; no relief claimed.

respondent_arguments.text: Partition fraudulent to defeat widows' rights, never acted upon, joint possession continued.
12 lands joint from adequate nucleus (151 acres Rs143 assessment, income Rs5-6k).
Challenged all alienations including Ex.159 in plaint paras 4,7 and schedule.

court_reasoning.text: Concurrent finding of lower courts that partition sham (no Panchas, unequal division, no house mention, to defeat widows, joint possession post-deed) is finding of fact not to be disturbed; evidence supports (witnesses 1-4 believed).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unequal division strong circumstance indicating not genuine; brothers continued joint.

court_reasoning.text: Sham pretence does not effect severance; needs definite unequivocal intention; mere declaration in bogus deed insufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited Merla Ramanna v. Chelikani Jagannadha Rao.

court_reasoning.text: Adequate nucleus proved (151a Rs143, income sufficient, low acquisition cost Rs4800/30yrs); burden shifts, no proof of separate business income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No direct evidence of cotton business dealings; DW evidence rejected.

court_reasoning.text: Plaint paras 4,7 and schedule challenge all alienations; Ex.159 without consideration (minor defendant 3, guardian Gowdappa, no property).

holdings.text: Partition deed sham, not effective; no severance of joint status.
Sham deed does not sever joint family status.
12 lands joint family properties; plaintiff entitled to share.

precedents_cited.case_name: Balu Sakharam Powar v. Lahoo Sambhaji Tetgura
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench Bombay HC on widow's adoption power post coparcenary end; overruled later.
Widow's adoption power continues post last coparcener death or partition; relates back, revives coparcenary.

precedents_cited.case_name: Merla Ramanna v. Chelikani Jagannadha Rao Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Sham pretence does not sever joint status.
Burden shifts if nucleus adequate; prove self-acquisition without joint aid.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Law (Mitakshara)
statutes_cited.relevance: Joint family status, severance, adoption by widow, nucleus presumption for joint property.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Bombay High Court judgment dismissing defendants' appeal and allowing plaintiff's cross-objection; partition sham, 12 lands joint, all relevant alienations not binding; decree for partition stands.
outcome.relief_granted: Partition decree with plaintiff entitled to share in joint properties.

key_quotes.text: The unequal division of the lands in the so called partition deed is a strong circumstance which indicates that the transaction was not genuine.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key evidence supporting sham partition finding.

key_quotes.text: If, however, the expression of intention is a mere pretence or a sham, there is in the eye of law no separation of the joint family status.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rules on ineffective severance by sham deed.

key_quotes.text: Proof of the existence of a joint family does not lead to the presumption that property held by any member of the family is joint...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States law on burden for joint property presumption with nucleus.
